Abstract.AbstractText: Neurological symptoms and varying levels of central nervous system (CNS) immunopathology have been described in COVID-19. Recent reports have suggested an increased level of innate immune activation associated with CNS border areas, as well as with a compartmentalized cytokine response and a dysregulated, autoreactive cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) immune profile. However, it remains contested whether these changes reflect bystander effects of systemic inflammation or relate to CNS-specific viral infection. We summarize some of the key findings pertaining to this ongoing debate and highlight directions for future investigation.
